Award.AwardTitle: Sustainable urban development in the Sun Corridor: Finding engineering alternatives through coupled WRF-urban land surface modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1435881 (Wang). Rapid urbanization is associated with substantial modifications of land use and land cover (LULC), producing complex socio-ecological urban landscapes. Changes in LULC have profound impacts on urban-land-atmosphere interactions, with modification of the transport of energy, water, and tracers over built terrains. Well-known effects of these changes include the urban heat island (UHI) and the emission of greenhouse gases and pollutants, which will likely be exacerbated by anticipated climate change. In this project, the researchers will use development scenarios of Arizona's Sun Corridor developed jointly by city planners and researchers as prototypes for investigating urban system dynamics. The Sun Corridor is one of the fastest growing urban areas in the U.S. Rapid expansion of the Sun Corridor has attracted increasing research attention on many socio-ecological issues such as the UHI effect and regional hydroclimate impacts. Despite this effort, there is a lack of a novel physical modeling framework to investigate how innovative engineering design and socioeconomic planning can help to mitigate adverse environmental effects. This project aims to bridge this gap. The central hypothesis is that scenarios for future urban growth derived from numerical modeling can reveal the interplay between land use change and regional hydroclimate leading to novel outcomes for urban sustainability. To address this, urban system dynamics including human-environment interactions need to be faithfully represented by multi-scale modeling frameworks (MMF) at high resolution with statistically quantified uncertainty.

In this project, the researchers will develop an MMF by integrating the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model with a state-of-the-art urban land surface model (LSM) to capture anthropogenic stresses and coupled transport of water and energy in urban canopies. The major outcome of the work will be the application of the integrated WRF-LSM for assessment of urban planning strategies. The result of simulations will shed light on how engineering infrastructure can ameliorate urban stresses, for example the adoption of green infrastructure to mitigate UHI. The work is expected to provide guidelines of sustainable urban development for land use and water resource planners, embracing various dimensions including water resources, hydroclimate, and engineering infrastructure. In addition, model uncertainty characterization in conjunction with scenario analysis, will provide insight into the vulnerability of urban environments to LULC and climate changes. Though this study is focused on the Sun Corridor, research findings are expected to have implications to other cities. This project will actively engage stakeholders and personnel from local cities and water resources and land planning agencies. The research team will seek participation and feedback from stakeholders in modeling efforts, scenario development, and interpretation of research findings relative to local cities and agencies throughout the project duration. Two-way communication between the project team and stakeholders will be conducted through technical briefings and workshops organized by the Decision Center for a Desert City (DCDC) at the Arizona State University. For example, LULC characteristics under future urban development will be gathered from city planners as the boundary conditions to the integrated WRF-LSM model. Meetings with stakeholders will be facilitated by auxiliary 3D graphic presentation and other innovative dissemination mechanisms. In addition, this project will support one research engineer and one graduate student at the Ph.D. level, who will be actively engaged in education and outreach activities throughout the project duration. Research findings of this study will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate-level courses, and disseminated to scientific communities as well as broader audiences, through conference presentations, peer-reviewed journal publications, and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome Report

 

Rapid urbanization is associated with substantial land use and land cover changes, producing complex socio-ecological urban landscapes. This has led to some severe environmental issues such as the well known urban heat island effect, which is highly likely be exacerbated by anticipated climate change. In this project, we assessed the sustainability of urban development in various scenarios of Arizona?s Sun Corridor developed jointly by city planners and researchers. 

 

The scientific outcomes produced by this project covers a wide spectrum of research activities and achievement, embracing the three major dimensions of sustainability, viz. economical, environmental, and social pillars. Our investigation probed into many fundamental research problems, ranging from the population growth as the underlying driver of urban development to urban planning strategies, and from the development of advanced numerical modeling tools to search in solutions in addressing emergent patterns under future climate. In particular, the major scientific outcomes of this project include:

(1)  The development of multiscale multiphysics urban modeling tools that represents the state-of-the-art in the field of urban environmental studies. We developed or employed a number of novel numerical techniques including the latest urban climate model, advanced Monte Carlo algorithm, statistical projection of urban population growth, computational fluid dynamic model of urban flows, and turbulent atmospheric dispersion, to name a few. The use of these modeling tools are highly transdisciplinary, involving environmental and mechanical engineering, meteorology, atmospheric science, geography, urban planning, and computer science. The developed integrative modeling framework was used primarily to capture the complex interplay between dynamics and processes arising from human and natural systems in the coupled urban water-energy-climate nexus.

(2)  The evaluation engineering solutions and urban infrastructure to ameliorate anthropogenic stressors, to improve thermal and air quality in cities, and to enhance the urban environmental sustainability in general, using cities in the Sun Corridor as study area (especially the Phoenix metropolitan). Extensive research effort was devoted to study, in particular, the impact of urban green infrastructure (lawns, urban trees, green roofs, etc.) on reducing the elevated temperature in cities. Towards this end, the aforementioned numerical modeling framework was employed, together with rich repositories of longterm environmental monitoring, field observation, satellite dataset, and data analysis techniques. 

(3)  The design of urban development guidelines for stakeholders including, e.g. city and landscape planners, policy makers, water resource managers, infrastructure designers, etc. This was achieved via extensive modeling and analysis of various urban development scenarios in the Sun Corridor and beyond (e.g. cities in the Colorado River Basin and the Contiguous United States), using the modeling tools and engineering solutions developed in this project. The scenario analysis ranged from local cities to regional and continental scales, including, e.g. the planned city expansion of Arizona?s Superstition Vistas to the total urban growth of all U.S. cities projected by the Environmental Protection Agency towards the end of the century. 

 

With respect to the broader impact, this project has actively engaged stakeholders and personnel from local cities and water resources and land planning agencies. The outreach activities were carried out via two-way communications, mainly through technical briefings and workshops organized by the Decision Center for a Desert City at the Arizona State University. Participation and feedbacks from stakeholders were incorporated into modeling efforts, scenario development, and interpretation of research findings to local cities and agencies throughout the project duration. The project team has developed strong collaboration with a number of local and national organization, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research, Central Arizona Project - Long Term Ecological Research, Urban Climate Research Center, and institutions such as Princeton University, Cornell University, and University of Reading. In addition, this project supported 4 graduate students, 3 at Ph.D. level and 1 Master, and contributed significantly towards their academic training via educational, research, and outreach activities. Throughout the project duration, it saw the completion of two Ph.D. dissertations (both won dissertation awards), one Master thesis, and one undergraduate Honors Thesis at ASU. In total, the finding generated from this project has led to the publication of 37 peer-reviewed journal papers and numerous invited talks and oral/poster presentations in meetings, conferences and symposiums at international, national, and local levels. Major research findings has also been incorporated into multiple undergraduate- and graduated-level courses, for educating the new generations of engineers, urban planners, and scientists for future urban development.
